he had to resign. But the precedent is a bad one. As I wrote last September, when Keith Vaz , the Labour chairman of Commons home affairs select committee, was upping the ante, Andy Coulson 's antagonists seem to be forging a new and frankly preposterous politico-legal doctrine of executive responsibility: namely, that a man should not only lose the job he holds at the time of the wrongdoing, but all subsequent jobs. On this sinister basis, one strike and you are out- forever. Andy Coulson has now lost two very senior positions in less than four years without a single allegation against him having been proved. Politics- and government- will be poorer without him. But more honourable and

the past. Howard Stern to David Letterman : sorry about your sex scandal( video) Instead of deflecting Howard Stern 's apology, David Letterman responded with candor and a bit of reciprocal praise. "You have been very, very nice to me on the radio and viciously ugly to me on the radio and I except both with equanimity because I know a little bit about how you operate and I'm still fond of your talent and your ability and what you've represented to the United States of America-and of course, the world.
